paper_abstract: This account describes a new pharmacophore-based de novo design method of drug-like molecules (PhDD). The method PhDD first generates a set of new molecules that completely conform to the requirements of a given pharmacophore model, followed by a series of assessments to the generated molecules, including assessments of drug-likeness, bioactivity, and synthetic accessibility. PhDD is tested on three typical examples, namely, pharmacophore hypotheses of histone deacetylase (HDAC), cyclin-dependent kinase 2 (CDK2) and HIV-1 integrase (IN) inhibitors. The test results demonstrate that PhDD is able to generate molecules with novel structures but having similar biological functions with existing inhibitors. The validity of PhDD together with its ability of assessing synthetic accessibility makes it a useful tool in rational drug design. (C) 2010 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
paper_title: PhDD: A new pharmacophore-based de novo design method of drug-like molecules combined with assessment of synthetic accessibility
